channel.title: Eventing on Rotational Labs
channel.description: Recent content in Eventing on Rotational Labs

item.title: Welcome to Ensign U!
item.description: Like any new tool, Ensign takes a little time to learn. But take it from us (a bunch of seasoned data science experts) – it will open up a new world of data science applications for you. Check out this beginner-friendly introduction!

item.title: What is Incremental Machine Learning?
item.description: Most of us got into data science because it’s exciting (if chaotic) and there’s a constant stream of new ideas, which is thrilling (if intimidating). But if learning is all about keeping up, why can’t our models do it?

item.title: Using River and Vowpal Wabbit to Build Real-Time Machine Learning Models
item.description: Real-time ML models continually learn on new data as soon as it arrives, so they’re less susceptible to concept drift and data drift. Read on to learn how to use River and Vowpal Wabbit to build real-time models in Python.

item.title: Streaming NLP Analytics Made Easy With HuggingFace LLMs and Ensign
item.description: Thinking about using a large language model (LLM) at your organization? Check out this tutorial to see how to bootstrap an MVP using an open source pre-trained model from HuggingFace and a free Ensign account.

item.title: Building My First Event-Driven NLP Application
item.description: A few weeks ago, I’d never used an event stream before. Read on to hear how I built my first event-driven data science app — the biggest challenges, my lessons learned, and a couple of key takeaways!

item.title: MLOps 101: A Fresh Approach to Managing Models with Event Streams
item.description: If you can’t deploy your models, you might feel frustrated, but you aren’t alone — only 1 in 10 data science projects ever gets deployed. The fix? We need to shift our mental model towards “thinking in events.”

item.title: Async or Swim: A Developer's Guide to Wading into Asynchronous Processing
item.description: The Go programming language provides powerful tools for managing concurrency, but robust asynchronous code requires us as developers to design around uncertain tasks and manifold queues. Step through an async codebase with us in this post!

item.title: Unlocking Real-Time Insights for Data-Driven Success
item.description: Profitable businesses rely on their own data to grow, make smart choices, and delight their customers. Easier said than done! While a batched approach can provided limited success, real-time data analytics often give better ROI.

item.title: Welcome to the Age of PostSQL
item.description: Calling all programmers! It’s time to get a bit more curious about data storage, because we’re about to enter the age of PostSQL…

item.title: ESG is a Data Problem
item.description: A new SEC proposal will make publicly traded orgs disclose ESG data like environmental impacts and workforce stats. Many anticipate challenges to compliance, but a new approach to data synthesis is here to help.

item.title: Mastering the Art of Data Freshness
item.description: Two decades ago Clive Humby proclaimed “data is the new oil”, marking an economic shift towards data products. But, if the intervening years have taught us anything, it’s to think of data more like fresh fruit.

item.title: Introducing Ensign
item.description: Have you always wanted to build an event-driven system, but couldn’t justify spending the cognitive overhead or platform engineering costs? Introducing Ensign – eventing made easy!

item.title: Prototyping Event-Driven Applications With Watermill
item.description: Event-driven architectures (EDA) are enjoying a resurgence in interest due to many organizations’ need to accelerate rapid prototyping and get by with smaller, more cross-functional teams. In this post, we’ll demonstrate how to get started prototyping EDAs with the open source package Watermill.

item.title: The Eventing Platform Landscape
item.description: Kafka and PubSub and Kinesis, oh my! Which eventing platform is best? In this post we’ll explore the three primary categories of eventing systems and understand their similarities, differences, and key use cases.
